sentence.content: SAM WALTON was arguably the most important retailer of his generation.

sentence.content: The son of an Oklahoma real-estate broker, he opened the first general store in what was to become the Wal-Mart chain in Bentonville, in the backwaters of Arkansas, in 1950, writes Martin Dickson.

sentence.content: By 1991 the chain&apost;s sales had risen to nearly Dollars 44bn, making it the world&apost;s largest retailer in terms of revenues, and the Walton family probably America&apost;s richest.

sentence.content: The chain&apost;s success stemmed both from Mr Walton&apost;s personality and willingness to challenge accepted retailing orthodoxy.

sentence.content: He was a frugal, modest man who worked extremely long hours from a spartan room in his Bentonville headquarters but delighted in getting out of the office to tour stores and meet customers and staff, whom he insisted on calling &apost;associates.&apost;

sentence.content: He would deliver pep-talks to employees extolling the virtues of thrift and customer satisfaction, long before these became fashionable management buzz-words.

sentence.content: Eight years ago, when Wal-Mart&apost;s profits were better than expected, he kept a promise to staff by dressing in a grass-skirt to dance the hula on Wall Street.

sentence.content: Also essential to Wal-Mart&apost;s growth was its pioneering of high volume, cut-price retailing throughout the year, rather than the periodic sales which rivals relied on to generate customer loyalty.

sentence.content: It was precisely such locations which became the bedrock of the business, though in the process Wal-Mart put out of business hundreds of small main street stores, prompting bitter resistance in some towns which Mr Walton tended to blunt with generous charitable donations.
